conclusion: Analyze forces acting on latch D to find normal force magnitude in self-locking state.
Free-body diagram of latch D shows forces: kx (spring force), N (normal force), f1 (friction with lock groove E), f2 (friction with housing A), F (external force).
In self-locking state, forces balance so latch remains stationary.
Resolve forces into components perpendicular and parallel to inclined surface of latch.
Perpendicular equilibrium: N = kx cos(theta) + f2 sin(theta).
Parallel equilibrium: f1 = kx sin(theta) - f2 cos(theta).
Maximum static friction force: f1m = mu N, f2m = mu N'.
Substitute f1 = mu N and f2 = mu N' into equilibrium equations.
Equations: mu N = kx sin(theta) - mu N' cos(theta) and N = kx cos(theta) + mu N' sin(theta).
Assume N' â‰ˆ N to eliminate N'.
Solve for N: N mu (1 + cos(theta)) = kx sin(theta).
Calculate N using theta = 30 degrees: N = kx / (mu (2 + sqrt(3))).
Final answer: Normal force magnitude is kx / (mu (2 + sqrt(3)).
